ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: By analyzing academic texts written by scholars with differing perspectives in the field of international relations, I learned how to develop my own opinion about the interactions between actors, institutions, and organizations at the global level. The arguments proposed by these texts exposed me to game theory, the application of economics to political thought, and even psychological approaches, which enriched my study of the three main paradigms of international relations. In addition to grappling with various theoretical schools of thought, I learned how to apply these abstract theories to concrete historical examples in order to offer a coherent argument in the final essay.
Learned about major IR paradigms, causes of war and other international conflicts, international institutions and organizations.
Communicating with others and effective reading skills
I learnt the basics of political science which helped me discover my true interests within the area.

I learned about different lenses or frameworks through which international relations can be viewed and applied them to real situations. I also developed research and composition skills through the policy memo assignment.

Critical Analysis, reading multiple academic papers, applying theories in a comprehensive manner while comparing limitations and benefits,  and understanding the arguments being made in a nuanced manner.
Key insights into basic IR principles
how to view the world through the three scopes of international relations
I learned how to study efficiently, communicate with classmates, and write an efficient essay under time constraints. It was an incredibly fulfilling experience.
I gained a strong understanding of international relations. I learned how to analyze certain situations in a global context.

A good foundation into the study of international relations, particularly the three main schools of thought and how they might be used to evaluate, understand, and make predictions about international situations.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The strengths of the course undoubtedly lie in the way that the course is structured and taught. The two discussion-based weekly class meetings, which enabled us to hear the voices of our peers, combined with the video lectures and long readings made for a satisfying experience. I was able to independently draw my own conclusions from the text before listening to the videos and observing whether my peers thought the same way. Both in the video lectures and Zoom classes, the professor used dynamic, humorous, simple examples to illustrate broader concepts in IR that enabled me to remember the grasp the topics with more clarity.
The class could be improved with one more written assignment, perhaps about one of the readings in particular. The research paper was a valuable part of the class, but it also made it so that our only opportunity to write about the readings was during the final. One more assignment would have been welcomed, though not necessary.
As a summer online course, all of the lectures were asynchronous and live sessions were discussion sections. I felt disconnected from the actual lectures, though the discussions were interesting.
More classes throughout the week

Everything was very clear and although at times some topics got harder to understand and because of the time we didnt have enough time to get through them in more depth our professor and TA always made sure we were on track and answered any doubts we had
This course followed a very logical sequence of topics that were each very informative and useful. I only wish that we would have had more time to apply concepts to historical examples.
Strengths were the live sessions discussing the readings, lecture concepts, and beyond to supplement learning and helped me better understand the concepts beyond the materials provided pre-class.

I think this course is a great introduction to this discipline. If I were to improve it I would maybe add some variety, so instead of individually answering questions about the readings, some days we could have a debate or deliver group presentations about a particular topic.

The courses progression of material learned was very logical and made sense as we got through the course, and classes reinforced what we learned on readings. One bug weakness of the course is that a lot of the material in the online lectures that we had to watch were not really covered or important to the rest of the course.

I think that the online format does have a few setbacks, but overall, I think that the strengths are clear. The lectures are easy to refer to and pay attention to, the professor and TF were both available, and it was an engaging course. I think one of the primary weaknesses of the course was the amount of lectures and reading assigned, as it could sometimes lead to confusion and/or small periods of burnout. However, it's a summer class and that's expected.

I really like the discussions of the class because it made the content more understandable and engaging. But, it is sometimes hard to get through the lectures because they are long (but it also the nature of summer classes since time is limited).

I liked how it was discussion-based, it made class interesting. I thought that the reading was interesting but sometimes unnecessarily long/some parts unnecessarily complicated, as in we would read it but never talk about it or think about it again.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: While I have not taken any other course at Yale (hence my inability to respond to 7/8 above), I would absolutely recommend it to another student seeking to delve into the field of IR. The course covers a plethora of topics, significant developments in the field, noteworthy authors, contemporary connections, and even other subjects (like sociology, psychology, game theory, etc). The concepts were broken down meticulously, and despite the challenge that the readings sometimes offered, they were rewarding since they built on one another.
Yes, if you are a Poli Sci or Global Affairs major. It's good stuff to know.
yes, very interactive

Of course, I developed new skills and engaged with students who had similar interests and were sharing opinions that enriched my understandings for each of the topics, our professor was always well prepared and open to any questions we had towards any topic helping us achieve our best performance even if we were complete beginners.
I would recommend this course to students of any major as it was very engaging, well organized, and informative.
Yes, though the schedule and pace of the course was quite fast the workloads is manageable and the classes are stimulating.

I would recommend this course to a first-year. I took it too late, therefore my experience was not as great. But I think it would be interesting and intellectually stimulating for someone starting their Yale career.
I would if you are interested in learning foundational international relations content.
this is great for prospective poli sci and global affairs majors

I think so. I think it was a great introductory course of International Relations and the overall structure of the course made it easy for anyone to come into the class and start learning IR. It allowed me to see the world in an entirely different perspective.
I would if it wasn't in the summer session. I really liked the material and the course, but it was sometimes difficult to manage all the workload in the span of only 5 weeks.

Yes, especially to someone like me who was looking for an introduction into political science. It's interesting, I feel like I learned a lot that I'd never known, learned to think in new perspectives, readings are interesting, and it's not a ton of pressure.
